hints.content:
To make a $15^\circ$ angle, we move the [[☃ definition 1]] to the middle dot of the protractor.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1299f3df47f619de110198ba2b46629dd5ddf53b)

Next, we line up one of the rays on the $0^\circ$ line of the protractor.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c34abdafbfeb958b006da197267d12ef7027c8d3)

Finally, we move the other ray around until it is lined up with the $15^\circ$ measurement on the protractor.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e31d26ee06ed1c69bdf2c07e91e47062e171162a)

The following angle measures $15^\circ$.  
*The rays may point in a different direction, but the amount of rotation between them must be the same.*

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/76a03e7ddffff9c541f775d0e47522cdea6c65c4)

To make a $30^\circ$ angle, we move the [[☃ definition 1]] to the middle dot of the protractor.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1299f3df47f619de110198ba2b46629dd5ddf53b)

Next, we line up one of the rays on the $0^\circ$ line of the protractor.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c34abdafbfeb958b006da197267d12ef7027c8d3)

Finally, we move the other ray around until it is lined up with the $30^\circ$ measurement on the protractor.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/a6dc468d1c3808bcdb348a1c5bad01e6a617a6dc)

The following angle measures $30^\circ$.  
*The rays may point in a different direction, but the amount of rotation between them must be the same.*

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/8dabfb450a78b9d4572d4011c8084009a25fbe2d)

To make a $45^\circ$ angle, we move the [[☃ definition 1]] to the middle dot of the protractor.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1299f3df47f619de110198ba2b46629dd5ddf53b)

Next, we line up one of the rays on the $0^\circ$ line of the protractor.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c34abdafbfeb958b006da197267d12ef7027c8d3)

Finally, we move the other ray around until it is lined up with the $45^\circ$ measurement on the protractor.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2edcc4903fcacf76613fe61af94f5d1323209e1a)

The following angle measures $45^\circ$.  
*The rays may point in a different direction, but the amount of rotation between them must be the same.*

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1334d4369ff09316e05f3c80e5b68d01158e8d10)

To make a $65^\circ$ angle, we move the [[☃ definition 1]] to the middle dot of the protractor.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1299f3df47f619de110198ba2b46629dd5ddf53b)

Next, we line up one of the rays on the $0^\circ$ line of the protractor.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c34abdafbfeb958b006da197267d12ef7027c8d3)

Finally, we move the other ray around until it is lined up with the $65^\circ$ measurement on the protractor.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/da1a947694aeb8e9d8a913f837e9c482e6646f11)

The following angle measures $65^\circ$.  
*The rays may point in a different direction, but the amount of rotation between them must be the same.*

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7379820ff5814dbca8964f203946a067364236da)

To make a $80^\circ$ angle, we move the [[☃ definition 1]] to the middle dot of the protractor.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1299f3df47f619de110198ba2b46629dd5ddf53b)

Next, we line up one of the rays on the $0^\circ$ line of the protractor.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c34abdafbfeb958b006da197267d12ef7027c8d3)

Finally, we move the other ray around until it is lined up with the $80^\circ$ measurement on the protractor.


![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/01a20d4bf02df6a688e1b017e4afedbda70215cf)

The following angle measures $80^\circ$.  
*The rays may point in a different direction, but the amount of rotation between them must be the same.*

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e18fd828301601b4965b39d47f0b868450fecec9)

To make a $110^\circ$ angle, we move the [[☃ definition 1]] to the middle dot of the protractor.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A protractor shows points plotted at 160 and 180 degrees. Rays are drawn out from the vertex in the protractor's center through each point.

hints.content:
Next, we line up one of the rays on the $0^\circ$ line of the protractor.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A protractor shows points plotted at 0 and 180 degrees. Rays are drawn out from the vertex in the protractor's center through each point.

hints.content:
Finally, we move the other ray around until it is lined up with the $110^\circ$ measurement on the protractor.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A protractor shows points plotted at 0 and 110 degrees. Rays are drawn out from the vertex in the protractor's center through each point.

hints.content:
The following angle measures $110^\circ$.  
*The rays may point in a different direction, but the amount of rotation between them must be the same.*

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: An angle is formed by two rays extending out from a common point. The size of the angle is slightly larger than a right angle.
